section.title: Formula and Environments
section.para:
Like functions, model formula such as mpg ~ wt + cyl also have an associated formula. We can create a formula as a stand-alone object with, e.g.,
frm = b ~ a
We can examine its structure with
str(frm)
Class 'formula' language b ~ a ..- attr(*, ".Environment")=<environment: R_GlobalEnv>
We see that there is an attribute associated with the formula and in this case it is the global environment. Like functions, the environment of a formula is the environment in which it is defined (unless explicitly set to be different.) So if a formula was created in a call to a function, its environment would be the call frame in which it was created.

Environments on formula allow functions manipulating a formula to find the associated variables referenced in the formula. We'll look at this and how it can be somewhat surprising in some respects. Again, we'll construct an experiment we can explicitly debug and understand in , rather than just stating the rules. Let's create two variables a and b:
set.seed(12312) a = runif(10) b = 5 + 2.34*a + rnorm(length(a))
Now, consider the formula
b ~ a
As we saw, this has the global environment associated with it.

Note also that b ~ a doesn't actually use the values of a and b. The formula is symbolic and will its contents will be evaluated later. It is like the quote function which doesn't evaluate its argument. It is like (but not the same as) parse in that it's contents will be used later. The expression b ~ a is a call to the function ~ which is a .Primitive function. That means it immediately passes its un-evaluated arguments to code and does not follow 's standard evaluation model. In other words, it uses non-standard evaluation! So it doesn't actually get the value of a or b.

Consider the call
coef(lm(b ~ a))
This calls coef which locates on the search path and matches the arguments to the parameters. The call to lm is also evaluated in the global environment and the same rules apply. The formula b ~ a is also evaluated in the global environment since this is a top-level expression. So the formula's environment is the global environment just as it would be if we had done this in two steps
frm = b ~ a coef(lm(frm))
The answer we get is
(Intercept) a 5.097029 2.618424

How does evaluate the call to lm(b ~ a). We have described the general rules of finding the function (lm), creating the call frame with a variable for each parameter, matching the arguments to the parameters, and evaluating the expressions in the body of the function with the call frame as the environment for the evaluation. However, like library, rm, ?, and a few more, lm uses non-standard evaluation (NSE). And this is made more complicated by how formulae work.

The call lm(b ~ a) passes the formula to lm. lm uses an explicit call to the eval function to create the design/model matrix for the regression. Actually, lm behaves even more unusually in that it constructs the call it passes to eval by adapting how it itself was called. We can see this by debugging the call to lm
debug(lm) lm(b ~ a)
After stepping through the initial expressions, we see the sequence of commands
mf <- match.call(expand.dots = FALSE) m <- match(c("formula", "data", "subset", "weights", "na.action", "offset"), names(mf), 0L) mf <- mf[c(1L, m)] mf$drop.unused.levels <- TRUE mf[[1L]] <- quote(stats::model.frame)
We have seen match.call. This returns are original call with the parameter names explicitly matched and added, i.e.,
lm(formula = b ~ a)
Next, we match the parameter names in the call to find formula, data, subset, etc. and we then keep only those elements of the call, discarding any other arguments. Why, because we are the arguments in the call to lm to actually call model.frame in the stats package. And lm doesn't want to have to check which arguments were passed to it and pass those on to model.frame. Instead it does this meta-programming on how it was invoked/called to create the corresponding call to model.frame. So the next two expressiins add a named argument drop.unused.levels with a value of and changing the function being invoked in this call object t stats::model.frame. So at the end of this sequence of expressions, we can see that mf is
stats::model.frame(formula = b ~ a, drop.unused.levels = TRUE)
and has class call.

Next, lm evaluates this call with
mf <- eval(mf, parent.frame())
This explicitly calls eval and specifies an environment in which to evaluate that call. This environment – computed as parent.frame() – controls where will look for variables in the call. parent.frame looks along the call stack, not the search path of this call frame. In our case, parent.frame is the global environment since our call to lm is the only call in the current call stack.

So let's debug the call to model.frame
debug(model.frame)
This stops in
debugging in: stats::model.frame(formula = b ~ a, drop.unused.levels = TRUE) debug: UseMethod("model.frame")
This is the method and will dispatch to model.frame.default and will debug that for us as it is related to model.frame. We step through the expressions in model.frame.default and we get to
if (missing(data) && inherits(formula, "data.frame")) { if (length(attr(formula, "terms"))) return(formula) data <- formula formula <- as.formula(data) }
We didn't provide a value for the data parameter in our call (to lm that was mimiced to call model.frame). But formula does not inherit from data.frame, so this condition is false. And then we get to
formula <- as.formula(formula)
and then
data <- environment(formula)
So model.frame will use the environment of the formula as the source of the data, i.e., the place in which to look for symbols. Recall that the environment of our formula is the global environment. And after a few more expressions, we get to
variables <- eval(predvars, data, env)
predvars is
list(b, a)
and data and env are the global environment. So this call to evaluate will find a and b in the global environment.

What would happen in the following
f = function() lm(b ~ a) f()
Where would find b and a and how?

What about
f = function() { a = runif(10) b = pi * a + rnorm(10) lm(b ~ a) } f()

Now, we will switch from finding the values for a and b in the global environment to providing them in a data.frame.
d = data.frame(a = a, b = b) coef(lm(b ~ a, d))
We actually have two instances of a – one in the global environment and one as an element in the data.frame. Which one did use? It doesn't matter, in this case, since they are the same. But it would matter if they were different. So which did it use? We can read the help file, or simply know, or use the debugger to step through the computations as we did before. , and model.frame.default specifically, will use the values in the data.frame, not those in the global environment. We can also verify this by removing a from the global environment and seeing if there is an error about not finding a:
a1 = a rm(a) coef(lm(b ~ a, d))
This succeeds and gives us the same answer as we originally got.

We'll now make this a little more interesting. We'll use lm's weights parameter to do weighted least squares. We'll use two sets of weights, one where all observations have weight 1 and another which are random numbers between 1 and 2, i.e.,
w1 = rep(1, length(b)) w2 = runif(length(b), 1, 2)
When we use these
coef(lm(b ~ a, weights = w1)) coef(lm(b ~ a, weights = w2))
we get
(Intercept) a 5.097029 2.618424 (Intercept) a 5.305530 2.194265
respectively. So we get different estimates for a (and the intercept) as we expect.

We might expect 's usual computational model is in effect here. Specifically, in the call to lm, matches the expression w1 to the weights parameter and creates a promise to evaluate w1 in the global environment in which we made the call to lm. And certainly, the result we got are consistent with this. However, it is not the case. We are finding w1 via a slightly different mechanism which happens to give the same result – in this case.

Let's create a new column in our data.frame d and we'll name it w1
d$w1 = w1
Again, we call lm
coef(lm(b ~ a, d, weights = w1))
and we get the same answer.

Now, let's set the w1 to have the other weights
d$w1 = w2
and call lm
coef(lm(b ~ a, d, weights = w1))
Now we get
(Intercept) a 5.305530 2.194265
So we are using the weights from w2. This indicates that lm and model.frame.default are looking in the data.frame when evaluating w1. This is very different from 's standard computational model we described.

Let's create our formula more explicitly and give it its own environment (just like we can for a function.) We create an environment and create variables in it named x and y, using the original values of a and b from the global environment.
e = new.env() e$x = a1 e$y = b
We create our formula and examine its environment
frm = y ~ x environment(frm)
It is the global environment. We now change this to be
environment(frm) = e
y ~ x <environment: 0x7fd22963a238>
We can now use this formula without specifying the data argument as model.frame.default will use this environment to find x and y
coef(lm(frm))
(Intercept) x 5.097029 2.618424
And again, we'll create a variable named w1, this time in e with weights from w2
e$w1 = w2
And now
coef(lm(frm, weights = w1))
gives
(Intercept) x 5.305530 2.194265
showing that it used the weights from w1 in e rather than those in w1 in the global environment.

This is non-standard evaluation and it means we don't use the regular rules for evaluation. So now we have at least two computational models. This makes it hard to reason about code. If you are luck, you get an error when you do the wrong thing. Often, you get the wrong answer and that is much worse than an error.

NSE is a powerful feature. But it needs to be used wisely and sparingly. NSE is convenient for programmers to do interesting things. However, it places a significant burden on the users of functions that use NSE because they cannot reason about what will happen using a single, familiar computational model. Instead, they have to carefully learn how each function that uses NSE will actually behave.
